creator.name: Vrijmetselarij
creator.his_func: During the second half of the 18th century, Freemasons became active in the Dutch Caribbean colonies. Lodges were established (and dissolved) in nearly all the colonies. In 1777 there were ten lodges on the Dutch Antillean islands; in 1778 there were six in Paramaribo with over 200 members. After being set up, these lodges had to request formal recognition or a constitution by a grand lodge, which was not necessarily a Dutch grand lodge. Between 1761 and 1780 there was regular correspondence with the grand lodge in The Hague. Between 1816 and 1837 the lodges in the West Indies, however, fell under the administrative authority of the grand lodge in Brussels.
creator.notes: In the publication  “Overzicht van Loges onder het Grootoosten der Nederlanden …” (Den Haag 2003), some lodges are recorded on Curaçao, St Eustatius, St Martin and in Paramaribo, Berbice and Demerara, including a list of documents and names of persons as applicants of a constitution letter or as founders of a lodge.
